content: You Who Legislate Evil
Laws that make misery for the poor,
Exploiting defenseless widows,
What will you have to say on Judgment Day,
Who will you get to help you?
A sorry sight you’ll be then, huddled with the prisoners,
Even after all this, God is still angry,
Doom to Assyria!
“Doom to Assyria, weapon of my anger.
I send him against a godless nation,
I command him to strip them clean, rob them blind,
But Assyria has another agenda;
He’s out to destroy utterly,
Assyria says, ‘Aren’t my commanders all kings?
Didn’t I destroy Calno as well as Carchemish?
I’ve eliminated kingdoms full of gods
So what’s to keep me from destroying Jerusalem

When the Master has finished dealing with Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he’ll say, “Now it’s Assyria’s turn. I’ll punish the bragging arrogance of the king of Assyria, his high and mighty posturing, the way he goes around saying,
“‘I’ve done all this by myself.
I’ve wiped out the boundaries of whole countries.
I charged in like a bull
I reached out my hand and took all that they treasured
Like a farmer gathering eggs from the henhouse,
And no one so much as fluttered a wing

And on that Day also, what’s left of Israel, the straggling survivors of Jacob, will no longer be fascinated by abusive, battering Assyria. They’ll lean on , The Holy—yes, truly. The ragtag remnant—what’s left of Jacob—will come back to the Strong God. Your people Israel were once like the sand on the seashore, but only a scattered few will return. Destruction is ordered, brimming over with righteousness. For the Master, -of-the-Angel-Armies, will finish here what he started all over the globe.

Therefore the Master, -of-the-Angel-Armies, says: “My dear, dear people who live in Zion, don’t be terrorized by the Assyrians when they beat you with clubs and threaten you with rods like the Egyptians once did. In just a short time my anger against you will be spent and I’ll turn my destroying anger on them. I, -of-the-Angel-Armies, will go after them with a cat-o’-nine-tails and finish them off decisively—as Gideon downed Midian at the rock Oreb, as Moses turned the tables on Egypt. On that day, Assyria will be pulled off your back, and the yoke of slavery lifted from your neck.”* * *
Assyria’s on the move: up from Rimmon,
through Migron,
They’ve crossed the pass,
Ramah trembles with fright.
Cry for help, daughter of Gallim!
Madmenah takes to the hills.
The enemy’s soon at Nob—nearly there!
At the mount of dear daughter Zion,
